importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Publication year of Baek Se-hee's memoir 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki', which became a bestseller in South Korea and significantly raised public discourse on mental health.
Year when the English translation of Baek Se-hee's memoir was released, leading to international popularity and inclusion on the Sunday Times Bestsellers List and a New York Times recommendation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2018 to 2025 represents the rise in global recognition of Baek Se-hee's work and its impact on mental health conversations, especially during the ongoing global mental health awareness movements.

keyTakeAways: Baek Se-hee, a South Korean author, died at the age of 35, leaving behind a legacy of honest and accessible mental health writing.

Her memoir 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki' (2018) and follow-up 'I Want to Die but I Still Want to Eat Tteokbokki' (2019) brought widespread attention to dysthymia and the complexities of depression.
The book became a bestseller in South Korea and gained international acclaim, reaching the Sunday Times Bestsellers List and receiving a New York Times recommendation.
Baek's writing offered a relatable and human portrayal of mental health struggles, helping reduce stigma around depression and therapy.
She donated her organs—heart, lungs, liver, and both kidneys—saving five lives, demonstrating her commitment to giving back even in her final days.
Her younger sister, Baek Da-hee, and translator Anton Hur paid tribute to her life and impact, emphasizing her kindness, empathy, and influence on readers worldwide.

summaryOfNewsArticle: South Korean author Baek Se-hee, known for her bestselling memoir 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki,' died at the age of 35. Her book, which candidly explores her struggles with dysthymia and depression while highlighting small joys like eating tteokbokki, became a cultural phenomenon in South Korea and gained international acclaim after being translated into English in 2022, reaching the Sunday Times Bestsellers List and receiving a New York Times recommendation. Baek wrote a follow-up memoir in 2019 detailing her ongoing mental health journey. She donated her heart, lungs, liver, and both kidneys, saving five lives. Her younger sister and English translator Anton Hur praised her for her empathy, honesty, and profound impact on readers worldwide.
title: Baek Se-hee, author of bestselling memoir ‘I Want To Die But I Want To Eat Tteokbokki,’ dead at 35
